question.title: "flutter_plugin_android_lifecycle:compileDebugJavaWithJavac" fails after updating Android Studio
question.body:
The app was running smoothly on emulator and on a real phone till now.

The problem is that after I upgraded to the most recent version of Android Studio, I try to run my project and get the following error:

Execution failed for task ':flutter_plugin_android_lifecycle:compileDebugJavaWithJavac'.

Could not resolve all files for configuration ':flutter_plugin_android_lifecycle:androidJdkImage'.
Failed to transform core-for-system-modules.jar to match attributes {artifactType=_internal_android_jdk_image,org.gradle.libraryelements=jar, org.gradle.usage=java-runtime}.

Execution failed for JdkImageTransform: C:\Users\User\AppData\Local\Android\sdk\platforms\android-34\core-for-system-modules.jar.
Error while executing process C:\Program Files\Android\Android Studio\jbr\bin\jlink.exe with arguments {--module-path C:\Users\User\.gradle\caches\transforms-3\484d354a4158c88badf69c3f94d831e0\transformed\output\temp\jmod --add-modules java.base --output C:\Users\User\.gradle\caches\transforms-3\484d354a4158c88badf69c3f94d831e0\transformed\output\jdkImage --disable-plugin system-modules}

Do I need to rebuild something or the update deleted a config I had? From what I've been reading it seems like a Java problem but can't pinpoint exactly what the problem is.

I have tried configuring the PUBSEC.YAML and even adding JAVA_HOME on the environments without any result. I even reinstalled Android Studio.

answers.body:
Do File > Invalidate Caches... in your Android Studio.

and try to build your app again.

Update: If issue persists

In your terminal, navigate to your <project-directory>\android

cd android

Then perform build gradle cache clean.

./gradlew clean

I suspect you're dealing with build cache issues. Therefore, all you need to do is clean the existing build cache and then rebuild for your updated Android Studio.

Update: Also, don't forget the common command of Flutter in cleaning build caches...

flutter clean;
flutter pub get;

This will ensure that your Flutter project is rebuild entirely.

79634717.body: If you can switch back and forth between a working and an issue-ridden setup, you can more effectively investigate the root cause of the problem. Using an outdated tool can lead to negative impacts at the API level for your Android target. However, it depends on your use case.
I went back to my previous Android Studio Version and it worked again.
@AnthonyVonDerKreuz, let me know if my updated answer provides development in resolving your issue.
i already did that but the problem still persist, i want to point that i am using VS Code.
